Award.AwardTitle: AMPlifying the Simulation of Clouds and Precipitation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Properly simulating clouds is critical for accurate prediction of clouds and rainfall in weather and climate models. There are two common ways in which small-scale cloud processes are represented in atmospheric models; these are known as bin microphysics schemes and bulk microphysics schemes. Bulk schemes are simple models that execute quickly while bin schemes are much more complex but run slowly â€“ in fact, too slowly to be used in weather forecasting or climate prediction. This project will use a new model, called the Arbitrary Moment Predictor (AMP), which benefits from the accuracy and flexibility of bin schemes to improve bulk schemes. AMP acts as a lens. It allows a weather model to see a bin scheme as though it were a bulk scheme. By changing the view, it will become possible to understand how best to implement bulk schemes in models for the first time. The results have the potential to lead to a major shift in the design and development of future weather and climate models.

AMP predicts size distribution moments of cloud droplets and rain drops like existing bulk schemes, but the process parameterizations are identical to those used by a bin scheme. It is flexible in that it can predict mass mixing ratio and one or two additional arbitrary distribution moments. There will be two major parts of the work. 1) Large eddy simulations of warm phase stratocumulus clouds with two bin schemes and with two versions of AMP corresponding to each bin scheme will be compared to assess fundamental limitations of bulk schemes. Such a direct comparison between bin and bulk schemes has not been possible before. 2) Additional simulations will be run using AMP with alternative combinations of predicted moments. Simulations will be rigorously assessed with available observations to explore the possibility that nonstandard moment combinations should be used to improve simulation of clouds and precipitation. Such a possibility has been suggested based on observational evidence but has not been tested in 3D simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this award, we continued developed a new liquid-processes microphysics scheme called the Arbitrary Moment Predictor (AMP). AMP is structurally distinct from previous microphysics schemes in that the choice of predicted drop size distribution properties (moments) can be easily specified by the user rather than being intrinsic to the structure of the scheme. AMP can also be configured to use separate hydrometeor categories for cloud droplets and raindrops, as is traditionally done in microphysics schemes, or it can be configured to use a single liquid hydrometeor category. Finally, AMP is a “bulk” scheme but it uses “bin” scheme process parameterizations. Comparing simulations that use AMP with those that use the underlying bin scheme from which AMP is built provides us with a way to cleanly compare a bulk scheme with a bin scheme to understand the fundamental structural limitations of a bulk scheme. Such comparisons can also guide improvement of bulk schemes. Such improvement is imperative since bin schemes are too computationally expensive for use in global climate and weather models.

Under this award, we published three papers (two of which contributed to a doctoral dissertation) which document the continued development of AMP and its use for understanding bulk schemes. One paper compares AMP with bin schemes using AMP in a traditional two-category configuration (Hu and Igel 2023, https://doi.org/10.1029/2022MS003303). Although bin schemes are typically considered to be “better” than bulk schemes, we find that simulations with AMP and simulations with AMP’s underlying bin scheme produce simulations that are remarkably similar to one another; much more similar than simulations run with different bin schemes. We performed a careful series of process-denial simulations and found that collision-coalescence was the single most important process for causing differences between simulations with AMP and simulations with AMP’s underlying bin scheme.

Igel et al. 2022 (https://doi.org/10.1029/2022MS003039) examined ways to improve the agreement between AMP and its bin scheme for the collision-coalescence process. Potential solutions included increasing the number of predicted properties (moment) in a traditional two-category configuration, changing the set of moments that are predicted, changing the arbitrary size threshold that distinguishes cloud droplets from rain drops, and using a single liquid hydrometeor category. We showed that a single liquid category could outperform a traditional two-category configuration, even when the single liquid category configuration had fewer total predicted moments. This result is particularly noteworthy for two reasons. First, predicting more properties is not necessary for improved performance. Second, a single liquid category is a fundamentally different structure for a bulk microphysics scheme than currently exists in any operational weather or climate model.

Igel et al. (2022) only tested one process in a box model. Hu and Igel (2024) extended this work to test the single liquid category approach in a single-column model and in a fully 3D model with all liquid-phase microphysical processes. Here we again demonstrated that the single liquid category approach is as good or better than the traditional two-category approach in nearly all of our test cases.

The success of AMP, as demonstrated through the publications supported by this award, has prompted others to begin adapting it for operational use in global models in its single-liquid category configuration. A single liquid category scheme is a fundamentally new way to approach liquid microphysical processes. ALL prior operational schemes have had an explicit separation of cloud droplets and rain. We are optimistic that the single liquid category approach will allow us to move past persistent problems with autoconversion (and other processes) that have hindered us from making more progress in simulating global clouds.
